>> Narrator: Hey, the House of Lords isn’t
some giant house party for rich old men, but

14.text:
who are the Lords and why do we have them?
The Lords started off as a kind of advisory

19.text:
council to the king, who was much more powerful
back then.

23.text:
They met up at Westminster every now and then
to discuss matters of state, but in 1215 King

30.text:
John, of Robin Hood fame, was forced to sign
the Magna Carta sharing power with the nobility.

37.text:
Trade became more and more important, leading
to the rise of a new merchant class. By the

43.text:
14th century, Edward III had two groups of
advisors divided into chambers, the Lords

50.text:
and the Commons, made up of lesser knights
and merchants.

55.text:
This is why we have two houses in parliament.
As time passed, the Commons became increasingly

60.text:
dominant and the King became less powerful.
In 1649 King Charles was even executed by

68.text:
The balance of power between the houses swung
firmly towards the Commons. From that day

74.text:
on, inheriting seats made the people feel
like the Lords were only for the privileged.

79.text:
As society moved on and cultures changed,
the questions arose, how had these people

85.text:
earned their place? How can they represent
the public? In 1958 the life peerages act

91.text:
introduced women into the house and radically
changed who was in the Lords.

97.text:
From then on, any man or woman could come
into the house based on what they had achieved

101.text:
in their career. The Lords act of 1999 reduced
the number of hereditary peers in the house

107.text:
and stopped Lords passing their seat to their
own family.

111.text:
A panel was made to help the Prime Minister
decide who was brought into the house, so

115.text:
that now the house is made up of people from
all walks of life, political peers, cross-bench

121.text:
peers, as well as hereditary peers and bishops.
They all use their experience from inside

127.text:
and outside of parliament to check and challenge
government. So what does the House of Lords

135.text:
The house has three main functions. To question
and challenge the work of the government,

140.text:
to work with the commons to shape laws and
to investigate issues through committees and

145.text:
debates, to help improve the way the country
is governed.

150.text:
The House of Lords is currently the second
busiest legislative chamber in the world,

155.text:
right after the Commons. Each chamber is laid
out in the same way as the Commons, the government

160.text:
party on the one side, the opposition on the
other.

164.text:
Peers who don’t belong to any political
party are known as cross-benchers, as they

168.text:
sit on the cross benches opposite the wool
sack. The wool sack is the Lord Speaker’s

174.text:
seat. Back when wool used to be our main trade,
this seat was supposed to remind the Lords

180.text:
It was and still is stuffed with the wool
from hundreds of sheep from around the commonwealth.

186.text:
Strange seats aside, the Lords is different
to the Commons because there’s no majority

190.text:
for any political party. The party in power
does not necessarily have the most seats.

197.text:
As the Lords are not elected, they’re less
caught up in party politics and can concentrate

201.text:
on their three main functions. So most people
have some preconceived idea of what the Lords

207.text:
are, but the reality is quite different, what
do you think?
